content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You are moderately cautious and may take risks but generally prefer to avoid them. You like to have some degree of security and predictability. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 40$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 40$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 20$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

Given my cautious nature and preference for predictability, I would choose strategy 'R' in this game, denoted as {R}. This is because if both of us choose R in each round, we get a higher payoff of 45$ per round compared to choosing B where the maximum payoff is only 20$. However, since it is an anonymous player and I don't know their strategy, there is a chance they might pick B more often. So, if I choose R and my opponent chooses B in a round, I will lose that round and receive no money. But considering the long-term advantage of choosing R outweighs the risk of occasional losses, I would still stick with my choice of {R} to maximize my potential earnings over 75 rounds, assuming the opponent's strategy is unknown.
You chose R. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 45$. Your opponent's payoff is 45$. Please play the next round.

In the next round, I would continue choosing strategy 'R', denoted as {R}. Even though both of us received a high payoff of 45$ in the previous round by choosing R, it doesn't guarantee that our opponents will stick to the same strategy in future rounds. By continuing with my cautious approach, I aim to maintain a higher expected long-term payoff over multiple rounds. It's important to note that in each round, there is still a chance for either of us to switch strategies, which could potentially affect our overall earnings. So, I would stick with strategy {R} for now.

However, if my opponent continues picking B, I will again receive no payoff. But in the long run, I would like to maintain a higher expected payoff over multiple rounds by sticking with strategy {R}, even though the immediate outcome may not always be favorable.
